projectPurpose: A lightweight geocoding library written in pure Rust to convert location names or addresses into geographic coordinates.
platforms: Rust ecosystem (likely cross-platform where Rust is supported)

alternatives.name: Nominatim
alternatives.license: Open Source (LGPL-2.1 or later for code, ODbL for data)
mainFeatures: Open Source geocoder based on OpenStreetMap data

alternatives.name: Photon
platforms: Server-side (requires Java, Elasticsearch), accessible via API
mainFeatures: Open Source geocoder for OpenStreetMap data

alternatives.name: Google Geocoding API
platforms: Web (API), Client Libraries (Java, Python, Go, Node.js, Rust)
mainFeatures: Converts addresses to coordinates and vice-versa

alternatives.name: GeoPy
mainFeatures: Python client for multiple geocoding services
Supports various geocoding APIs (Nominatim, Google, etc.)

alternatives.name: Geoapify Geocoding API
alternatives.license: Proprietary (Paid with Free Tier), Permissive Data Use

marketPositioning: Airmail is positioned as a lightweight, pure Rust geocoding library. It targets developers within the Rust ecosystem who require in-application geocoding without the need to integrate with external services or manage separate server-based geocoding instances like Nominatim or Photon. Its focus on being lightweight and pure Rust differentiates it from language-agnostic APIs (Google, Mapbox) and libraries in other languages (GeoPy), emphasizing performance, memory safety, and seamless integration within Rust projects. While it may not offer the extensive global data coverage or advanced features of large commercial APIs, its appeal lies in providing a native, efficient geocoding solution for Rust applications.
